intro: Ophrys aranifera var. vierhapperi, commonly known as the Four-veined Bee Orchid, is a rare and specialized orchid species found in specific habitats across Europe. It is characterized by its intricate flower structure, which mimics the appearance of a female bee, a feature evolved to attract male bees for pollination. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodland floors or along stream banks. Its flowers have a distinctive four-veined lip that plays a crucial role in its pollination strategy. Due to habitat loss and environmental changes, this variant is considered vulnerable and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
